How to read this table: The report you've pasted above will be parsed into individual headings, with one row per issue type. The 'matches' column is not meant to match the 'label' column, but is instead meant to match the specific finding from the IllIllI-bot report's headings (seen here for the default page data). When there is more than one value in the 'matches' column, that means there are some instances that appear in multiple categories. For example, label '[L-05]' has matches 'L‑02_dup, D‑02_dup', which means '[L-05] Array lengths not checked' in the pasted report has some entries that may match either '[L‑02] Array lengths not checked' (valid instances) or '[D‑02] Array lengths not checked' (disputed/invalid instances) from The IllIllI-bot report.

The purpose of this tool is to ensure that two reports with the same issue get the same score for that issue. For example, the winning bot had '[L-10] Int casting `block.timestamp` can reduce the lifespan of a contract' as 'Low' severity, but looking at the 'matches' column (N‑57_dup), IllIllI-bot had the same finding as '[N‑57] Contract timekeeping will break earlier than the Ethereum network itself will stop working' with 'Non-critical' severity. A judge judging these two reports should give both '[L-10]' in this report, and '[N‑57]' in IllIllI-bot's report, the same number of points.
